metadata.titleEn: Whole rock and mineral geochemical data of gaowu leucogranite in Yadong area, Tibet, China
metadata.description: This data includes whole-rock major and trace geochemical data, plagioclase major element data, alkali feldspar major element data, muscovite major element data, tourmaline major element data, and monazite trace element data. The samples were collected from the Gaowu rock mass in the Yadong area, southern Tibet. The major elements in the whole rock were analyzed by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) glass melting sheet method; The trace elements in the whole rock were dissolved by mixed acid dissolution method and tested by Quadrupole Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (Q-ICPMS); The major mineral elements were analyzed by electron microprobe; The mineral trace elements were obtained by ArF excimer laser ablation system and quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer. The data obtained show that the Gaowu tourmaline muscovite granite shows the characteristics of high evolution magma.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in Excel format. The file name is "PlMaj", which represents the major element of plagioclase; "AfMaj" represents the major element of potassium feldspar; "MusMaj" represents the major element of muscovite; "TurMaj" represents the main element of tourmaline; "MnzTra" stands for monazite trace elements; "WRMajTra" represents the major and trace elements of the whole rock.

Quantification.Question: How many types of mineral geochemical data are collected in a dataset related to the pale-colored granite in the Gaowu area of Yadong, Tibet?

Definition.Question: What is the X-ray fluorescence (XRF) glass fusion method used for in the context of geochemical data collection?
Definition.Answer: The X-ray fluorescence (XRF) glass fusion method is used for analyzing the major elements of whole-rock geochemical data. This technique involves creating a glass bead from a powdered sample and then using XRF to determine the elemental composition, offering precise measurements of major elements in geological samples.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the geological processes involved from the geochemical data of major and trace elements in the rock and mineral samples collected from the Gaowu pluton in the Yadong area of southern Tibet?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical data of major and trace elements obtained from rock and mineral samples can indicate that the Gaowu tourmaline-muscovite granite exhibits characteristics of highly evolved magmatic processes. This inference is supported by the use of X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy and quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry to analyze the major and trace elements, and by electronic probe analysis and laser ablation systems for mineral composition.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on the accuracy and reliability of geochemical data analysis when employing XRF and Q-ICPMS techniques for major and trace element analysis in granitic rocks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of XRF for major element analysis and Q-ICPMS for trace element analysis in granitic rocks can lead to highly accurate and reliable data due to the sensitivity and precision of these methods. XRF provides robust data for major elements through its ability to analyze large sample areas, reducing heterogeneity issues, while Q-ICPMS offers high sensitivity for trace elements, allowing for detailed geochemical characterization. This combination can enhance the understanding of the geochemical evolution and composition of high-evolution magmas as observed in the granitic samples from the Gaowu pluton in Tibet.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives might researchers have when collecting geochemical data from both whole rocks and minerals in granitic bodies of regions like southern Tibet?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include understanding the geochemical characteristics and evolutionary history of the granitic bodies, such as the high-evolution magmatic features of the Gouwa tourmaline-muscovite granite, by analyzing major and trace elements in the whole rock and mineral components. This can provide insights into the geological processes and conditions during the formation of these granites.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures used to analyze the geochemical composition of rocks and minerals in the context of granitic formations in regions like southern Tibet?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The geochemical composition of rocks and minerals in granitic formations is analyzed through several methods. Whole rock major elements are examined using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) with glass fusion techniques. For whole rock trace elements, a mixed acid dissolution method is utilized followed by analysis with quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (Q-ICPMS). Major elements in minerals are determined using electron probe microanalysis, while mineral trace elements are obtained using an ArF excimer laser ablation system coupled with Q-ICPMS.
